body: Try calling AddGlobalIgnore in your profiles.
This is a known issue for some time. Find some way to set it, maybe a base class or reflection.
It is a known issue? Do we have another open for this?

@jbogard I guess some people knew about it for some time.  Guess no one brought it up.  More than likely this was a relic left over from the upgrade from a single static instance to IMapper.  Global no longer had the same meaning, as it's part of a Profile object, and no one had an issue with it until now.  Would need to become part of IMapperConfigurationExpression to give it same meaning again.
It's the same thing about global vs profile configuration. See #1629.

This is a bug, from my view. We have type map and property map actions for all maps, global ignores would make sense to apply globally, too. Principle of least surprise here.

I also think any configuration that affects matching members, if applied at the global profile, should apply globally.
I agree it's a bug, but the merging idea you had, between profiles and global, that seems messy to me.

I think if it says global it should apply globally.  If it can be called in a profile it's just be applicable for that profile.

It gets too confusing having the configuration act as both a profile and a global settings for other profiles at the same time.  That's why I like the idea of treating config as a profile only and the profile functions only apply to itself.  Now the global ignore needs to change cause that's misleading, but if you want global ignore that should only be in IMapperConfiugrationExpression interface and not IProfileExpression interface.

Maybe you need to do `cfg.Default.CreateMap<Foo,Bar>` instead of `cfg.CreateMap<Foo,Bar>` and then it will be Much clearer what does what instead of melding 2 different configuration interfaces together.

The way I saw profiles was a way to create maps, as well as a scope to apply mapping rules. The root profile is the "global" mapping rules, and profiles are for specific stuff.

We already do this today with property map actions/type map actions.

I'll spike out a PR and get some input.
@jbogard If the root profile is the global mapping rules, does that mean conventions should apply to all sub profiles, along with things like global ignore?
Yep. That was my idea. Basically all the members on IProfileConfiguration besides the methods, I'd have a way to combine those with the underlying config.

If you do that I worry about race conditions or else you are going to have to have to global config be implemented last as far as configs go.  I'm thinking all actions that used to work on the default profile, except create map, will now have to be an action that you need to run to all profiles after initialize function is complete.  They will then apply to all sub profiles.  Maybe order might not matter that much for things like conventions and ignores.

I think what I'll probably have to do is what I did with TypeMaps - make them super dumb, and build up intelligence around setting them up properly. Right now Profile is a bit too smart - especially around the CreateTypeDetails method.

issue.title: Apply Root Configuration to Profiles
issue.body:
Currently, root configuration is separate from profiles. This includes:
- AllowNullCollections
- AllowNullDestinationValues
- ConstructorMapping
- ShouldMapField/Property
- CreateMissingTypeMaps
- Naming conventions
- Global ignores
- Extension methods
- Conventions

To fix this, we need to segregate the profile configuration entity from the runtime profile configuration. To do so, I'm creating a new class, ProfileMap, to be the analog to TypeMap and PropertyMap to represent the final configuration for a profile.

This also means that when we build a ProfileMap, I can examine the root configuration and anything set in your profile, to build the final picture. In order to do so, many of the defaults need to be removed in the Profile class, in addition to making some of the values nullable so that I can detect if they're set or not.

The final picture is a bit cleaner, with the ProfileMap class containing behavior of "how do I create a TypeMap", and the Profile class containing behavior of "how do I gather Profile configuration".

body: This thread has been automatically locked since there has not been any recent activity after it was closed. Please open a new issue for related bugs.
